Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Novel Bio-inspired 3D Materials for Surface-Active Devices

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research project involves studying a new class of materials that can significantly improve the performance of currently available devices used in the energy, environmental, and biotech sectors of the economy. In recent decades, population growth, higher life expectancy and rapid industrialization have increased needs for water, energy, food, sanitation, and health care. For instance, the United States National Intelligence Council (USNIC) estimates that by 2030, societal demand in these areas will increase by 40-50%. Many of these increased demands can be addressed by advanced sensors, catalysts, membranes, and biomaterials that can, for instance, make it easier to remove chemical pollutants from water, detect and destroy pathogens, and carry out faster chemical and biological tests with improved precision and lower cost. Nanomaterials show great potential for such game-changing applications, but their use in actual devices has been rare, since they can easily escape into the surroundings posing high risk of material loss and environmental toxicity. This research project addresses this dilemma with a novel materials architecture that combines the power and efficiency of nanomaterials with the safety, durability and reusability of conventional solids.

The specific goal of the project is to investigate bioinspired three-dimensional surfaces that combine the functional advantages of nanomaterials with the structural advantages of conventional solids. Such materials can provide a novel multifunctional platform for custom-tailored catalysts, antimicrobial agents, sensors and/or bio-scaffolds. The design concept is to enrich the surface of porous solid substrates with carpet-like arrays of carbon nanotubes (CNT) that can be further customized with nanoscale catalysts, sensors and biomolecules for tailoring their interaction with surrounding fluids. This architecture mimics natural biological materials such as microvilli and capillaries, where the larger membrane supports progressively smaller specialized attachments. This approach can offer exceptionally high levels of solid-fluid interaction in very compact space. Moreover, different regions of the same substrate can concurrently provide multiple simultaneous benefits in a single filter, reactor, or bio-engineering platform. Currently available devices do not use this architecture, due to the complexities of bonding dissimilar components that create multiple unknown interfaces. This project addresses these complex issues, and explores the possibility of synthesizing such materials for solid-fluid interactions involving catalysis, signal detection and cell scaffolding through the following research tasks: (1) investigation of nano-carpets on porous solids, and their affinity for different fluids; (2) study of chemical & catalytic reactions at hierarchical surfaces; and (3) understanding biological interaction of nano-carpets with peptides and living cells. In parallel with the research, education and outreach components are being developed for undergraduates, science teachers, community leaders as well as governmental policy personnel.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Many advanced devices of today involve adsorbents, catalysts, sensors and bio-scaffolds, which depend predominantly on solid-fluid interactions. Nanomaterials can offer very significant advantages in this area, which has led to large number of fundamental studies, but not much progress is made in deployment of practical reusable devices using nanomaterials such as nanotubes and/or nanoparticles.  This is because nano-scale materials are difficult to handle, transport and package into conventional engineering devices, and pose potential health risks due to easy proliferation into the environment. In contrast, natural biological systems such as microvilli and dendrites make very effective use of nano-scale entities in the form of hierarchical solids, where the larger supporting unit (often a membrane) is anchored to progressively smaller functional attachments that offer nanoscale advantages to a robust reusable solid. The project investigated the use of this design concept in robust, reusable engineering devices by covalently bonding carpet-like arrays of functional nanomaterials (nanotubes, thin films, and nanoparticles) on larger solid substrates.  Hierarchical solid materials were successfully synthesized using plasma and chemical vapor deposition techniques, and in-depth analyses of their physical and chemical properties were performed.  Figure 1 shows one example of materials synthesized in this study. Some of these materials were activated with palladium nanocatalysts and were shown to be useful for rapid and complete degradation of persistent environmental pollutants, such as halogenated compounds (Fig 2). In parallel, another study was performed to investigate the interaction of these materials with living biological cells (glioblastoma and keratinocytes), and it was shown that surface wettability and carpet height together control cell growth mechanisms, which may be tailored for future biomedical applications such as tissue implants and/or skin grafts.
 
Intellectual Merit: This project offered a bold and radical approach to bio-inspired materials design, which can provide unprecedented benefits in a diverse variety of applications.  The topics cut across several research topics: surface modifications; catalytic materials, and interaction of nano-structured materials with fluids and biological cells.  Deeper insights were generated in the following scientific challenge areas: (i) strategic bond formation between dissimilar components of integrated hybrid solids (ii) chemical and catalytic activities of integrated multiscale hybrid solids, (iii) biological interaction of nanostructured surfaces and their dependence on macro-nano synergies. It was successfully demonstrated that bio-inspired porous structures can be synthesized by covalent bonding of nanotubes, nanoparticles and coatings on larger porous scaffolds. These materials can be functionalized with metal nanocatalysts for degradation of environmental pollutants. Their interaction with biological cell lines indicate biocompatibility and controllable cell growth that can be useful for design of future bio-medical implants. 


Broader Impacts: The broader impacts of this project were in the areas of product development and educational outreach. Key impacts include: (i) innovative approach of creating multiscale materials for a variety of environmental and biomedical applications; (ii) large number of outreach presentations to science teachers and community leaders highlighting how nanotechnology can provide solutions for environment, energy and health; (iii) development of undergraduate design projects: this directly supported a 4-member undergraduate capstone design team to test the use of these materials for oil-water separation membranes; and  (iv) individual research experience and mentoring for three undergraduate students.
